article.Heading: More spectrum, RJio entry may erode telecos margins: CRISIL
article.Summary: As RJio enters the market and more spectrum is auctioned in 2016-17, CRISIL Research believes margins will erode by 180 bps.
article.Body:
Below is the state of telecom industry as per CRISIL Research

Data traffic to spur revenue growth; 4G face-off, high spectrum payouts to keep returns subdued
India’s mobile telephony industry revenues grew 10-11% in 2015-16, led by higher data traffic (70% year-on-year for major telecom operators). Healthy growth in data volumes and data subscribers – spurred by increasing adoption of 3G and 4G services – will lift revenue growth to 11-12% in 2016-17.

To counter Reliance Jio Infocomm’s (RJio) entry (expected commercial launch in March-April 2016) into the sector, leading operators have advanced their 4G launches and are already offering 4G services in many circles.

Operators scrambling to grab high-usage, service-focused data subscribers will set off a tariff war but prices are unlikely to fall more than 20% from current levels.
Higher costs stemming from 4G rollouts and heavy marketing expenses have kept margins flat in 2015-16. However, as RJio enters the market and more spectrum is auctioned in 2016-17, CRISIL Research believes margins will erode by 180 bps.

Next round of spectrum auctions to put pressure on already leveraged balance sheets of operators

The next round of spectrum auctions, expected in the next 4-5 months, will put additional pressure on the already stressed balance sheets of operators (total debt for the sector was Rs 3 trillion as of March 2015).

Total capex over the past four years until 2015-16 is Rs 1.7 trillion; this is expected to increase to Rs. 3.2 trillion over the next 4 years. If operators additionally bid for 700MHz spectrum band, capex will further rise from these levels.
